The Egyptian system of government had many different social classes. At the top of the social structure is gods. The role gods played in the structure is that they were believed by the Egyptian to control the universe.  Next in the social structure was the Pharaohs. They were believed to be gods in human form and had absolute power over their subjects. Then came the vizier. They ensured that taxes were collected. "These high-level employees had mastered a rare skill in ancient Egypt- they could read and write." (paragraph 5). Next there were nobles and priests. Their jobs were to hold government positions and to please the gods. The middle class was mostly made up of crafts people. They sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus, products, tools and more. Lastly, at the bottom of the social structure were slaves and farmers. Slaves were forced to work on building projects while farmers tended to the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good shape, worked in stone quarries and finally built royal monuments.

The ancient Egyptian system of government was frequently compared to their famous pyramids. Starting at the top, the gods, which were believed to have the power of controlling the universe. Below was the "human form" of the gods, the pharaohs. The pharaoh leads the Egyptian until death, when a pharaoh dies his subordinates honor him by building massive tombs with many jewels. Right under pharaohs are nobles and priests. The difference between the two is that nobles manage the government and priests thrive in pleasing the gods. The vizier managed the taxes, they were below the priests and nobles.  The soldiers watched over builders when they weren't fighting. They were also under vizier but still respected. Coming to the middle class we have craftsmen and physicians, they normally sold jewelry, tools, pottery, and other such things. At the bottom of the pyramid were slaves and farmers. As a result, they paid a hefty amount of taxes. Of course, this is a way to move up the pyramid but it is fairly rare.

In ancient Egypt the social structure was like a pyramid. The less valued a class got the more people it would have.  Pharaoh's ruled over Egypt and were goalie. Then next on the ladder was Nobles/Priests. Priests pleased the gods, and nobles held government posts and they profited off of tributes paid to the pharaoh. Soldiers fought for the country. Then next was skilled workers. Physicians/craftsmen/women were all here. Craftsmen made and sold things to other places. Merchants and storekeepers sold good brought from artisans and traders. Slaves and farmers were at the bottom. Farmers kept canals and reservoirs, they tended their own farms, sometimes worked in stone quarries, and built royal monuments. They paid a large amount of their yearly harvest as tax. You could raise your social class as a kid by going to school and learning these traits.

The Ancient Egyptian Social Structure was one like no other! The social structure was like a pyramid! There were the very important people at the top, such as the pharaohs, and the less important people at the bottom, such as the slaves! These were called the vizier. They made sure taxes were collected. With the vizier worked the scribe! Scribe are very important because they were the only people who could read and write! Below them were nobles, and priests. These also people who affected the ways that the Egyptian lived. Soldiers came below with the responsibility of supervising many people! According to the text "soldiers also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves". At the very bottom were the slaves and farmers. Although they did most of the work, they weren't treated properly! This is the Social Structure of Ancient Egypt!

Different social classes were involved in the ancient Egyptian system of government. For example, the highest role would be pharaohs, or rulers. Pharaohs are considered to be gods in human form, and they are expected to protect Egypt from many dangers.  The pharaoh was appointed a vizier, or chief minister, to supervise and ensure that taxes were collected. Scribe helped the vizier keep government records. Scribe could read and write, unlike many people in Egypt. Right below the pharaoh, there were nobles and priests. Nobles could hold government posts. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods. There were soldiers whom supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in the building of individual structures, pyramids, and palaces. Slaves and farmers were at the bottom of the Egypt social structure. Slaves were exhausted from being put to work by the pharaohs. They were prisoners of war and were forced to put all their work into building projects and more. Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals, and more. They worked immensely. In addition, their taxes amounted to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest.

The structure of the ancient Egyptian system of government had multiple classes. The top class is gods and pharaohs as one was seen as a form of a god and the other was worshipped. Both were said to have extreme power and protection to them was top priority. Also, below pharaohs and gods were vizier, scribes, nobles, priest's and soldiers. Soldiers could be considered in the class lower than gods and pharaohs because they had to protect them and when not fighting as paragraph 8 states, "During long periods of peace soldiers also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in building such structures as pyramids and palaces." The middle las was made up of merchants, dealers, pottery makers, shopkeeper, and craftsmen/women. All provided services that were essential or looked pretty. Finally, at the lowest end there were slaves and farmers. Slaves worked hard at the pharaohs or nobles will and were treated terribly. While farmers worked hard just to get taxed 60% of their harvest. To summarize, the ancient Egyptian social structure were treated differently in their social structure while current ones though still treating others differently is more fair than the ancient Egyptian social structure.

At the top of the government, there is the pharaoh, who were believed to be gods in human form. They had absolute power over their subjects, and they were buried in chambers in huge stone pyramids once they die. They were entrusted with many things, such as protection. Directly under them were vizier, nobles, and priests. Vizier mastered reading and writing (which was rare in old Egypt), collected taxes, which were in grains so people could be fed during times of famine. The nobles held government posts, and benefited from tributes. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods. Soldiers fought in wars and supervised peasants, farmers, and slaves. Skilled workers (craftsmen/women and physicians) made up the middle class. They made goods, and merchants sold them to the public. Farmers and slaves were at the bottom of the social structure. Farmers were supposed to tend the fields, raise animals, keep canals and reservoirs in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. They paid heavy taxes equating 60% of their yearly harvest. Slaves were captured Pos who were forced to work on building projects and work extremely hard for the pharaoh.

To summarize the article, most people in the lower, more peasant like statuses has less of a chance of becoming anything more than a farmer.  Most of the time, they were locked in on that certain social class, for their entire life. However, the more unique, and important social classes were at the top, with some being the pharaoh, priests, and scribes. The more important people were mainly structured at the top, while the other, less important people were stuck at the bottom. My evidence for the summary clearly states in the text, " their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form. They had absolute power over their subjects." Meanwhile, if you were to compare this text to the second one provided, " At the bottom of the social structure were slaves and farmers. Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles." You would be able to see the fact that  most social classes on the lower end of the spectrum were treated poorly,  while the other, higher classes on the pyramid would be treated with respect.

In an article by History.org titled "EGYPTIAN SOCIAL STRUCTURE," the article explains the social hierarchy of ancient Egypt and how the government functioned. Not many were allowed in the process of governing. The pharaoh was one of them, since the, "people of Egypt believed that their pharaohs were gods,"(History.org, 3). The pharaohs and gods at the very top, they approved all the rules and controlled the army. After the pharaoh were the nobles. Nobles were very important, a the nobles were the only ones that could, "hold government posts".(History.org, 4) Other than the pharaoh, only they had control of such things, and they gained much wealth for working such jobs. Scribe, people who could read and write, worked with Views to keep government records of taxes. Even though there were many people who were slaves and farmers, they were so far at the bottom of the hierarchy, there was little chance of them having an impact on the government, otter than getting taxed 60% of their earnings. Unless they were essentially royalty, people didn't have a giant impact on the Ancient Egyptian government.

They were servants who often served nobles, or even the pharaoh.

The ancient Egyptian system of government was shaped like a pyramid. At the top, the pharaoh was believed to be the human form of a god. He would enact laws, collect taxes, and most importantly, protect Egypt. Right below him were the nobles and priests. "Only nobles could hold government posts"(History.org, paragraph 6) , and "Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods."(History.org, paragraph 6) These two classes made up the aristocracy; together, they helped the pharaoh run Egypt. At the middle of the pyramid, soldiers fought in Egypt's wars, quieter rebellions, and supervised the laborers who were building the pyramids. Skilled laborers were also in this class; "Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and other useful things."(History.org, paragraph 9). These people were the utility workers of Egypt: if you wanted something, this was the class most likely to have it. At the bottom of the pyramid, slaves and farmers produced the raw materials that kept Egypt going.  They paid heavy taxes, but didn't have to stay slaves or farmers. Some families saved money so their sons could  learn trades or become scribes.

The social structure of ancient Egypt had various roles.  In this order, pharaoh, government officials, scribes, artisans, farmers, and slaves. To start there are the pharaohs who held the most power and were believed to be gods in human form.  Pharaohs had various roles or jobs like directing the army, enacting laws at will. But the pharaoh mainly controlled the kingdom. Next, there are government officials which are the priest, nobles, and the vizier. The vizier helped assist the pharaoh and also made sure that all the taxes were collected. While nobles worked in government and priests made sure the gods were pleased. Then, there are the scribes, these people had learned a unique skill to read and write. So they kept the government records. Additionally, some artisans make pottery, papyrus, jewelry, tool, and lots of other useful objects. Some soldiers fought in battles and helped build monuments. Finally, there is slaves in farmers, their job was to work on projects for the pharaoh, tend to fields, raise animals, keep things in good shape. They also had to grow and harvest crops, as much as 60% of their yearly harvest would be collected for taxes. To conclude, the Egyptian social structure has very different components.

One way the ancient Egyptian system of government was structured was by social hierarchy classes. One piece of evidence showing that is: "Egyptian society was structured like a pyramid. At the top were the gods, such as Ra, Siris, and Isis."  Gods were at the top of the social pyramid then was the pharaohs: "Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form. They had absolute power over their subjects." The  pharaohs were in charge of everything and ruled their subjects. That is one way the ancient Egyptian system of government was structured. The  social classes were involved in this government by: "The pharaoh directed the army in case of a foreign threat or an internal conflict. All laws were enacted at the discretion of the pharaoh. Each farmer paid taxes in the form of grains, which were stored in the pharaoh’s warehouses. This grain was used to feed the people in the event of a famine." This shows how the pharaoh was in charge and the farmers, which were in a different social class (below the pharaohs), paid taxes and probably had no say in doing so. The pharaohs and farmers are treated differently. That how the social classes were involved in the government.

The Egyptian System of Government was based from slaves, all the way to pharaohs. Like modern-day ranking, pharaohs were the top in their government. I know this because in the text it clearly states; "Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form. They had absolute power over their subjects." Meanwhile, just below the pharaohs; the Noble Aims; (nobles and priests) were in second. Then, came the soldiers. second to last of the pyramid. I know this because the text clearly states; "Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. At the top were the gods, such as Ra, Siris, and Isis. Egyptian believed that the gods controlled the universe. Therefore, it was important to keep them happy. Under the gods, the Egyptian leaders, called pharaohs.  Pharaohs had absolute power over their subjects. After pharaohs died, huge stone pyramids were built as their tombs. Pharaohs were buried in chambers within the pyramids. Under the pharaohs, were the nobles and priests. Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods. Nobles enjoyed great status and also grew wealthy from donations to the gods. The pharaoh appointed a chief minister called a vizier as a supervisor. The vizier ensured that taxes were collected. Working with the vizier were scribes who kept government records. These high-level employees had mastered a rare skill in ancient Egypt, they could read and write.  Under the vizier and scribes were the soldiers.  Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. During long periods of peace, soldiers also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in building such structures as pyramids and palaces. Next, skilled workers such as physicians and craftsmen/women made up the middle class. Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and other useful things.

The Egyptian social structure  was in the shape of a pyramid. Each social class made a major impact on Egyptian society. At the top was the pharaoh, of which was considered a god themself. They ruled over Egypt and  guided their people, though this came with many responsibilities. One of the biggest being, keeping their people safe and away from danger. Right below the Pharaoh on the social structure, were nobles and priests. Though, only nobles were able to hold government posts. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods. The middle class was made up of skilled workers such as craftsmen/ women, and physicians. Craftsmen created and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus, products, tools, and many other items. There were also those who bought goods from artisans, such as merchants and storekeepers of which sold goods to the public.  Finally, at the bottom of the social structure were slaves and farmers. Those who were captured in war were made into slaves, and were also forced into working on building projects. However, farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good order, and many other useful activities to help the upper classes. It was almost impossible to move up the social ladder, although some boys who went to school and learned how to read and write were able to become scribes. Then, may possibly be able to move into a government position. This social structure formed ancient Egyptian society.

Ancient Egyptian social structure can be visualized as a pyramid, at the apex of which is Gods and Pharaohs. It was believed that Gods and Goddesses like Ra, Siris, and Isis controlled the universe at their whim. Pharaohs were believed to be living Gods in human form and given great power and responsibility. Assisting the Pharaoh was the vizier, or tax collector who used scribes, or high-level, literate record keepers. Below the Pharaohs were Nobles and Priests. Nobles held government posts and profited off of tributes to the Pharaoh while Priests held responsibility to please the Gods. One tier lower are Soldiers and Skilled Workers, or Artisan. Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings, also supervising slaves, peasants, and farmers in peacetime. Artisan such as physicians and craftsmen were middle-class people, Craftsmen making and selling jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and other useful things. To stimulate the economy, there were merchants and storekeepers who sold these goods to the public. At the bottom of the proverbial barrel are Slaves and Farmers. Slaves were captured Prisoners of War, forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the whim of the pharaoh and nobles. Farmers tended fields, raised animals, kept waterways in good order, worked in the quarries, and built royal monuments. Farmers paid as much as 60% of their yearly harvest as tax.

 "Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods." The Ancient Egyptian system of government was made up of many social classes.  At the top of the pyramid of power were gods.  Gods were feared and Egyptian  believed they could control the universe, by causing famine,  flooding, or death.   The Pharaohs were humans who were also considered gods.  They had absolute power, and when they died they were buried in tombs, which were huge stone pyramids.  Pharaohs were entrusted to providing protection and all laws were enacted by Pharaohs.  Pharaohs needed help with all their duties, and  often appointed a chef minister called a vizier.  The vizier ensured that taxes were collected, also,  the Pharaoh directed the army to protect the people.   Below the Pharaohs, were powerful nobles and priests.  Only nobles profited and could hold positions in government, and priests were responsible for pleasing the gods.  Nobles grew rich and enjoyed great status from donations to the gods.  Next,  soldiers supervised peasants, farmers, and slaves.  They fought wars and stopped uprisings.  Also, skilled workers such as craftsmen and doctors were the middle class.  At the bottom of the social structure were farmers and slaves.  Farmers tended the fields, raised animals,  kept reservoirs in good order, and worked in built the royal monuments.  Slaves were prisoners of war and were controlled by the pharaohs and nobles.  Ancient Egypt's social order contained manly social structures, each containing a group of people in different ranks of society.

In Egypt, there were many occupations and social classes involved in day-to-day living. In many instances if you were at the bottom of the social ladder you could climb up, you didn't have to stay a peasant you could work to bring your status up. Everyone worshipped the gods Ra, Siris, and Isis, but also they would worship their pharaohs like gods as well. Under the pharaohs were the priests, they had the responsibility to entertain or please the said god. The Chain of Command was placed to keep everyone in check, not one person could handle all the civilians and treasures without any aid. Like the tax collector, called a vizier like stated they were in charge of collecting the peoples' tax. They were also one of the rare instances who were able to read and write, that's how they were granted "vizier" Also the soldiers did many things as they would fight in wars or "quelled domestic uprisings". They were in charge of getting the slaves, farmers, and peasants to build palaces or the famous ancient pyramids. More skilled hardworking workers had occupations of craftsmen or women and physicians. This would mostly make up the middle-class people. The creative craftsmen would often make jewelry, papyrus products, pottery, tools, and many useful things people may need . Of course, you would need merchants to sell the goods to people who would pay for it.

The ancient Egyptian government was run by a Pharaoh. The Pharaoh was considered a God or God-like and was very highly praised. They had control over all their subjects and citizens. They usually were built pyramids for their tombs. Under the Pharaoh was a minister or vizier. The vizier's job was to collect taxes and to make sure everyone paid them.  Scribe worked with the vizier because they held government records. Scribe were important because they could read and write.  Then there were nobles and priests. Priests would feed and please the gods to make them happy.  Nobles would hold government posts and they profited from the gifts. There were also soldiers who would fight in wars. And workers such as craftsmen and women and physicians. They were in the middle class.  Then there were the merchants who sold goods to the citizens who bought them. At the bottom, there were farmers and slaves. The slaves were captured prisoners and they would be forced to work on buildings. Farmers did a lot for the Egyptian. They would take care of animals, tended the fields that provided food, kept canals, and worked in quarries. They did all this work and had to pay more than 50 % of their harvest in taxes. The social classes were involved because the people who worked for the Pharaoh were at the top of the pyramid. The middle was merchants, craftsmen and woman, jewellery, and more. At the bottom was the farmers and slaves.

The text states, "Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. Below the pharaoh was the vizier, the vizier was a supervisor and ensured that all taxes were collected. Also below the pharaoh were nobles and priests that were very powerful because only nobles could hold government posts. Priests helped the pharaohs please the gods. At the bottom are the slaves, slaves were the people that have been captured and forced to do work for the higher levels above them. As one can see, the Egyptian social structure back in ancient times had lots of social classes involved and every level had a job to get done.

The structure of the Ancient Egyptian government is is a system compiled with Different roles starting from the bottom, slaves, to the top, gods. Different social classes were implemented in the government by giving the different roles seperate jobs to aid in the progression of the society. According to the section 'Egyptian Social Structure' paragraph 1, "At the top were the gods, such as Ra, Siris, and Isis. Egyptian believed that the gods controlled the universe. Therefore, it was important to keep them happy." The gods were at the top of the pyramid based system. They are a very important and played a powerful role. Like the text says the gods were supposedly controllers of the universe and made very important decisions. According to 'The Chain of Command' paragraph 4," No single person could manage all these duties without assistance. The pharaoh appointed a chief minister called a vizier7 as a supervisor. The vizier ensured that taxes were collected." This was another important role in the system. It kept order in the civilization by collecting taxes and advising the Pharaoh. According to 'Noble Aims' paragraph  6," Right below the pharaoh in status were powerful nobles and priests. Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh." This role was also a heavily praised and respected role. Just like the text stated, the noble role was right below the Pharaoh and held government posts, the exercise of political authority over the actions, affairs, etc.

Different social classes were involved in the government because the Egyptian made poor and rich people have different jobs. Theage are the jobs that they did. Also known as the social pyramid. At the top of the pyramid their was the Pharos. Underneath the Pharos was the Government Officials.  Then under them were Priests. Next was the Scribe. After that were the Artisan. Finally under them were the Peasants. According to the text "At the bottom of the social structure were slaves and farmers. Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles. Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. Farmers paid taxes that could amount to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest—that’s a lot of hay! Social mobility was not impossible. A small number of peasants and farmers moved up the economic ladder. Families saved money to send their sons to village schools to learn trades. These schools were run by priests or by artisans. Boys who learned to read and write could become scribes, then go on to gain employment in the government. It was possible for a boy born on a farm to work his way up into the higher ranks of the government." As you can see. Each job had to do different thing. With this information it proves that different social classes were involved in the government.

At the very top were the gods, who were believed to be able to create life, bring famine, bring Death, cause flooding, and etc. Up next were pharaohs, who were believed to be the gods in their human form. They were tasked with ruling Egypt, protecting Egypt, and they had an assistant; the divider. The adviser's were to help the Pharaohs make sure that every member of Egypt played their taxes. Along with the divider's, there were scribes, whom which could read and write. They also kept government records. Right below them we have the Nobles and Priests, whom which Priests were tasked with pleasing the gods. Nobles were the only class that could hold government posts. Nobles enjoyed great status and grew wealthy from donations to the gods of Egypt. Up next we have Soldiers.  Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. They also supervised slaves, peasants, and farmers during times of piece. Just below them were Egyptian with jobs. These egyptian sold many useful things. Finally, at the bottom of the Egyptian society are the slaves, peasants, and farmers. Slaves were the fate of whom were captured in war, and slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles. Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in goog order,  worked in stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. Egyptian society was shaped like a pyramid, with the classes being more powerful as you go up and less powerful when you go further down.

The structure of the ancient Egyptian system of government revealed many ways the social classes were invoked in the government/the pyramids. At the high class of the government were pharaohs, views and scribes. The texts says, "No single person could manage all these duties without assistance. The pharaoh appointed a chief minister called a vizier7 as a supervisor. The vizier ensured that taxes were collected. Working with the vizier were scribes who kept government records. The Egyptian government and social class structure was similar to the structure of a pyramid. At the top were the gods and pharaohs becuase they held the most power. People believed pharaohs were gods in human form. Next, were the nobles and priests. People of this rank had duties to fulfill such as pleasing the pharaoh and gods. According to the article,  "All Egyptian-from pharaohs to farmers-gave gifts to the gods." Occupying the middle class were skilled workers like craftspeople,  and physicians, as well as artisans, traders, merchants and storekeepers. These people sold goods and other products to the public. Finally, at the lowest level on the social pyramid, were slaves and farmers. As the article states, "Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war." Slaves were forced to work on building projects and other difficult tasks that only people on the lowest level of the social class pyramid would do. The article says "Farmers tended fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good order, worked in the stone quarries and built the royal monuments." Farmers also paid taxes that could equal as much as 60% of their yearly harvest. The article also explains how social mobility was possible. Men could learn to become scribes and work their way up the social pyramid. However, their families would have to pay for a special school for them to do so. So, to conclude, ancient Egypt was made up of a pyramid of social classes and government that worked together to help Egypt function.

To summarize te structure of the ancient Egyptian system of government, The way that each social class was involved with the government is to one, starting off with the lowest bit of the pyramid comes the farmers and the slaves. The slaves are prisoners and are forced to work on building projects while the farmers grow and take care of animals and keep canals going. The farmers pay tax to the pharaoh (giving them hay income of a famine that gets stored in the warehouse) and they are the ones who provide the food. Next come the soldiers and craftsmen/woman. The soldiers help fight and also supervise the farmers/peasants when there is peace. The craftsmen make jewelry and sell things to the people and the merchants go trade and also give to the public. Nobles and Priests kept the gods happy making donations, etc. Vizier supervised the pharaoh. The pharaoh is the highest bit of the pyramid and is believed to be god/human. In the text in paragraph 1 it states, ''Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed t be gods in human form.'' Another price of evidence states,''It was possible for a boy born on a farm to work his way up into higher ranks of the government.'' (paragraph 13) In conclusion, this is the social structure of Egypt but you may change your role if you learn how to read and write, you may become a scribe and get employed in the government. Overall, all parts have a certain role in the government or in helping the government.

The ancient Egyptian system of Government was like a pyramid. The most important at the top, and less important at the bottom. Gods and pharaohs (gods who were thought to be disguised as humans) were treated the best, while slaves and farmers were treated far worse. First came the pharaohs and gods. They were who had to be tended for, cared for, and protected all the time. The Egyptian believed that they were the ones who controlled the universe, so in order for them to stay safe, they had to make sure they were happy. Then middle class, which were physicians and craftsman. The craftsman made and sold jewelry, papyrus, tools, and much more. People who were considered as a skilled worker. At the bottom of the ¨pyramid¨ were slaves and farmers. Slaves had to work very hard. They were forced to work on building projects. The farmers were very hard-working as well. The kept all canals and reservoirs in good shape, raised animals on the fields they took care of, and built the royal monuments. All while working in quarries. Farmers still had to pay taxes, but they paid taxes that could amount to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest. The Egyptian society was complicated but fair. Those who were not the best, were treated the worst. Those who were important, needed to be seen. Of course, back then everything and everyone thought differently. At the  top of the Egyptian government system was the pharaoh, he was in control of everything  and was believed to be a god in human form."Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form."  The pharaoh would appoint a vizier as a supervisor,  his job was to ensured taxes were collected."The pharaoh appointed a chief minister called a vizier as a supervisor. "Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh" Priests job was the please the gods." Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods."  Next were soldiers, their jobs were to fight in wars or quelled domestic uprisings, also look over the peasants, farmers, and slaves."Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings...soldiers also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves" At the bottom of the government were slaves and farmers. The vizier made sure that taxes were collected. Scribe would work with the vizier and they kept government records. They could read and write which in the time, was a rare skill and they had mastered it (The Chain Of Command Section). Only nobles could hold government posts, in the social pyramid, they were right below the pharaoh (along with priests). They profited from tributes in these positions. Nobles had great status and grew very wealthy from the donations to the gods (Noble Aims Section). Soldiers fought in wars or put an end to domestic uprisings. They also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved with building structures like pyramids and palaces during long periods of time. Physicians and craftsmen and woman made up the middle class. Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and much more. Merchants and storekeepers would sell these goods to the people (Soldier On Section). Now on the bottom of the social pyramid (or social structure as it is called in the article), slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. They were forced to work on building projects. They also worked extremely hard at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles. Wanting to change your social status was impossible to do. A very tiny number of peasants and farmers did go up in the economic ladder. Schools were ran by priests and artisans. Boys who could read and write would become scribes and would go into working for the government (The Bottom Of The Heap Section). That is pretty much all that was to be said for the different social classes in the government.

The ancient Egyptian social structure was very complex. In paragraph one it states that "Egyptian society was structured like a pyramid. At the top were the gods, such as Ra, Siris, and Isis."  The gods were believed to have the most power, and could essentially control what happened to Egypt's people.  Next to the gods was the pharaoh. paragraph two states that ancient Egyptian "leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form." People called nobles benefited from gifts to the pharaoh. After nobles came priests, who made sure the gods were happy. If the gods weren't happy, they could bring floods and other natural disasters. While the pharaohs were given a lot of power, they were also given a lot of responsibility. The pharaoh had to command the army and deal with taxes, which they hired a vizier for. The vizier made sure that taxes were collected. paragraph five states that "working with the vizier were scribes". The scribes were the only people who knew how to read and write, and they were in charge of the government records.  Soldiers were next on the social pyramid of ancient Egypt. They protected the country and made sure it was safe in case a conflict broke out.  Craftsmen created useful items like tools and pottery. In addition to these things, craftsmen also made luxury items such as jewelry.  At the very bottom of the social pyramid there were farmers and slaves.  Farmers took care of fields and animals, made sure canals and reservoirs were in good order, worked in stone quarries, and built royal monuments. Paragraph eleven states that "Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war".

At the top of the social pyramid are gods.  They had immense power, and could control their respective elements (Paragraph 1). Just below gods are pharaohs. Pharaohs were considered gods in human forms. They also had a load of power (Paragraph 1). Vizier were below pharaohs. The vizier insured taxes were collected. They also acted as a supervisor (Paragraph 4).  Scribe also worked with vizier. They were special, because they could read and write (Paragraph 5). Below all of these people were nobles and priests. Nobles were the only people allowed to hold government posts and profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh (Paragraph 6). Priests were the religious leaders of Egypt. They kept the gods content so that they wouldn't bring misfortune to Egypt (Paragraph 6). Soldiers were below those two. They fought in wars and forcibly ended domestic uprisings. When it was peaceful, soldiers supervised peasants, farmers, and slaves who got involved in creating structures like pyramids and palaces (Paragraphs  8-10). Physicians and craftsmen/women were part of the middle class. They made jewelry, pottery, and papyrus products, tools, and all kinds of useful things (Paragraph 9). Of course, people had to buy good from these people. The people who bought these things were merchants and storepeople. These people sold these goods to the public (Paragraph 10). At the bottom of the barrel, we have slaves and farmers. Slavery was often the fate of prisoners of war. They re forced to work on building projects, and toiled  at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles (Paragraph 11)

The structure of the ancient Egyptian system of government was structured like a pyramid. The pharaohs were at the top of the social class, believed to have been god like, or gods in human form. They had "absolute power over their subjects," (Paragraph 2.), perceived to have no limitation to what they could possibly do. Under the pharaohs, were the pharaohs second in command, known as vizier. They were the people that had to record if taxes were collected. They are supposed to help the pharaohs with his duties. Finally, the last social class within the government are the nobles. They are the only class that can hold government positions. They gained money through the tributes, or gifts paid to the pharaoh. Since we know the pharaoh was basically a god, they were either paying to him or the other core gods of their society, which included Ra, Siris and Isis. Every egyptian, including "pharaohs to farmers—gave gifts to the gods," (Paragraph 7.) Moving on, different social classes were involved in the government due to taxation and bureaucracy. For instance, although the pharaohs and state leaders held control over what the laws were,  people could still choose whether they wanted these laws or not. Additionally, an example of a different social class being involved in the government were farmers. Farmers were taxed up to 60% of their crop to the pharaohs annually, (Paragraph 12.) This allowed the pharaohs and nobles to distribute foods from warehouses if need be, such as in a famine or food shortage. Therefore, this is how the social structure of Egypt was built, as well as how other social classes helped within the government.

The ancient Egyptian system of government was structured like a pyramid.  Different social classes were involved and went down the stack like this: Pharaohs, nobles/priests, and farmers/slaves. According to the text, "Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form." This perfectly explains why pharaohs were at the top of the pyramid because the text also says the following: "Egyptian believed that the gods controlled the universe. Therefore, it was important to keep them happy." What better way to make somebody happy than making them rich and powerful? The next rung on the ladder was the one held by nobles and priests, however, these were not much lower than the pharaohs. Quote: "Right below the pharaoh in status were powerful nobles and priests. Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions, they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods."  This clearly shows that while below pharaohs, nobles and priests were still major important in Egyptian culture. Next were physicians and craftsmen. Quoted here, "Skilled workers such as physicians and craftsmen/women made up the middle class. Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and other useful things." The middle class was still needed and wanted, unlike the bottom of the pyramid, which was farmers and slaves. As I quote here, "At the bottom of the social structure were slaves and farmers. Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles." Also, "Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. Farmers paid taxes that could amount to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest—that’s a lot of hay!" These guys were given less happy lives by default.

No single person could manage all these duties without assistance. The pharaoh appointed a chief minister called a vizier as a supervisor. The vizier ensured that taxes were collected. Working with the vizier were scribes who kept government records. These high-level employees had mastered a rare skill in ancient Egypt — they could read and write. Right below the pharaoh in status were powerful nobles and priests. Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods. Nobles enjoyed great status and also grew wealthy from donations to the gods. All Egyptian—from pharaohs to farmers—gave gifts to the gods.Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. During long periods of peace, soldiers also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in building such structures as pyramids and palaces. Skilled workers such as physicians and craftsmen/women made up the middle class. Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and other useful things. Naturally, there were people needed to buy goods from artisans and traders. These were the merchants and storekeepers who sold these goods to the public.At the bottom of the social structure were slaves and farmers. Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles. Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. Farmers paid taxes that could amount to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest—that’s a lot of hay! Social mobility was not impossible. A small number of peasants and farmers moved up the economic ladder. Families saved money to send their sons to village schools to learn trades. These schools were run by priests or by artisans. Boys who learned to read and write could become scribes, then go on to gain employment in the government. It was possible for a boy born on a farm to work his way up into the higher ranks of the government. Bureaucracy proved lucrative.

The system of ancient Egyptian government is like a pyramid. The very top of the pyramid was the gods and the pharaohs because the gods controlled the universe and because the pharaohs were believed to be able to communicate with the gods so they were thought as god like. The gods controlled the universe and the pharaohs controlled everyone. The priest and nobles were next. Only nobles could hold government office. The priest were supposed to make the gods happy. After nobles and priest came the soldiers. The soldiers were the ones that fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. Soldiers were also the ones who supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in building such structures as pyramids and palaces. The people who were next after holders were scribes. A scribe recorded in writing the everyday life and extraordinary happenings in ancient Egypt. Their jobs were varied and included writing letters for fellow villagers who couldn't write, recording the amount of crops harvested. After the scribes came the merchants. Egyptian merchants carried products such as gold, papyrus made into writing paper or twisted into rope, linen cloth, and jewelry to other countries. Next after merchants were artisans. Artisan created the fine artwork that often covered temples, royal tombs, and other monuments. They worked in large groups to complete engravings, paintings, and hieroglyphs. Despite artisans' skill and creativity, the upper classes often viewed them as little more than common laborers. Next after artisans were farmers. Now we're on to the lower part of the prima with farmers. Farmers are the ones who harvest food. They also harvest papyrus for others(most likely scribes) to write on. Now we're on the ER bottom of the social prima with slaves and servants. The servants worked as cooks, butler, litter carriers, and as pharaoh's dresses. The male servants also worked on royal building projects or were sent to fight in the Egyptian army. Egyptian servants did not have many rights but were usually not treated poorly. Egyptian servants could not own or inherit land. Slaves were very important in ancient Egypt as a big part of the labor force, but they were also used for many other purposes. Many slaves were house servants, gardeners, farm labor, musicians and dancers of excellent talent, scribes, and accountants.

The social structure of classes in Ancient Egypt, weren't very different from todays social structure. The Upper class was filled up by pharaohs, the Middle class was filled up by priests, nobles, craftsmen, scribes, and merchants, and the Lower class was filled by slaves, and farmers. Now, all of these places were connected to the government. Their government was basically worshipping gods and goddesses. The pharaoh was connected to the government, because he of she was the ruler of Egypt, "Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form" (paragraph, 2). The Middle class was connected to the government because they either helped the pharaoh directly, or they had sustainable jobs to sell things to people, "Right below the pharaoh in status were powerful nobles and priests. Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tribute paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods... Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. During long periods of peace, soldiers also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in building such structures as pyramids and palaces" (paragraph, 6 and 8). The nobles and soldiers held the Middle class, because they weren't as wealthy as the pharaohs, but they had more money than the peasants, farmers, and slaves. The Lower class was connected to the government, because their jobs paid for their homes and food, "At the bottom of the social structure were slaves and farmers. Farmers paid taxes that could amount to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest- that's a lot of hay!" (paragraph, 11 and 12). All of the pieces of social structure were connected to the government, they were either the government, or they had to pay the government. The Ancient Egyptian government was not very different from ours today.

"Skilled workers such as physicians and craftsmen/women made up the middle class. Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and other useful things. Naturally, there were people needed to buy goods from artisans and traders. These were the merchants and storekeepers who sold these goods to the public." And at the bottom/base are the farmers and slaves. The farmers has to raise animals, take care of the fields, conduct some tasks in the stone quarries, construct royal monuments, and are responsible to keep the reservoirs and canals in shape. They also have to pay 60% of their annual harvest towards tax. "Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs  in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. Farmers paid taxes that could amount to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest—that’s a lot of hay!"  Although people can't raise their status, young boys can go to school to learn how to read/write and then can become scribes or can apply for employment in the government which would make their status rise. The slaves have to work on developing projects and put extreme effort at the direction of the nobles or pharaohs. "At the bottom of the social structure were slaves and farmers. Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles."

In the story, "The Jungle" by Upton Sinclair is about the meat industry and how they were packing spoiled meat in a sanitary manner.  It follows a guy by the name of Jonas, who had worked in one of the pickle room among the spoiled meat. The meatpacking that was conducted in the industry in Chicago was disgusting. The author, Upton Sinclair, explained how there were various ways in which the workers in the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat. Some of how workers would use or cover up spoiled meat were the action of rubbing the meat with soda to take away the smell, filling up ham with pickle, the workers also had a stronger pickle that destroyed odor, the invention of a new device by a person to extract the bone, from which the bad part generally lay, and insert in a white-hot-iron. These various ways in which the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat are all discussed in the second paragraph of the excerpt from The Jungle.

A few ways the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat was they would rub soda to take away the smell and would fill up the meat with pickles because it would destroy the odor but some would still come out spoiled. As is stated in paragraph 3 of this article,"Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference." The meat would be preserved with borax and be colored with gelatin to make it brown. If this is not disgusting the meat would be covered in rat dung, germs, saw dust, spit, and poison as it washes up on the floor.

First, when the factory could not use the spoiled meat for anything else, they "either [canned] it or [chopped] it up into sausage" (Sinclair 1). Second, "they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters" (Sinclair 2). The packers had a strong pickle "which destroyed the odor" (Sinclair 2). The spoiled meat "would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption" (Sinclair 3). The workers sometimes would "spit uncounted billions of consumption germs" (Sinclair 4).

They would take the bone out where the bad meat would be and insert a white hot iron in the hole."And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. The factory would pickle the spoiled meat or grind it and make sausage."Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." "And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. The meatpacking industry used several different methods to cover up spoiled meat just enough to be sold.  The first method described was pickling te meat, which, "[gives] to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose". Following the pickling,  "they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters". The second method was taking out all of the skin and bones of the livestock where most of the bad parts would generally be, and insert a white-hot iron rod into the hole.  From there, several different "styles" of boneless ham were created, including California. Adding on to that,  stainless bones were also created, where the thick skin of old hogs would be labeled "head cheese!"

The various ways the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat given below. For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage.It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white—it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption.

When the meat was spoiled they would chop it up and put it into sausage, "whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage." The factory would mask the scent of spoiled meat in order to be able to sell it. ". . . they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell [. . .] To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor--a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty per cent'" [2]. The workers would also mix up spoiled meat and other non-meat materials into sausage. "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor [. . .] rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together. [. . .] there were things that went into the sausage in comparison with which a poisoned rat was a tidbit" [4]. They would also mix preservatives with other meats to prevent them from going bad so quickly with chemicals such as borax and gelatin.

The meatpacking industry has taken advantage of consumers through the deception of not notifying them of the spoiled meat products they are receiving. Sausage that was old and moldy that no other company wanted would be seen as gold to some others; primarily to twist the situation.  They would put chemicals in the meat to take away the moldy look and the meat is off for consumption.  Deception was very common in the meatpacking industry and still is today, and some have no clue.

In the excerpt from the text "The Jungle," Upton Sinclair exposes the sanitary conditions found in meatpacking factories during the early 20th century in America. To cover up these atrocities, meatpackers used various techniques. Among these are pumping spelling hams with a "much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor . . . ." They also took whole hams that had gone completely bad and "Cut [them] up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed [them] with half a ton of other meat, [so that] no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference." In other cases, when there was "old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white -- it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over . . . ." These are just some of the many things done to hide the horrible meat produced from the factories.

The factory would use various ways to cover up or use spoiled meat. According to the article, it states, "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage." This shows how the factory uses spoiled meat and makes it into sausages or rather can it. Another way the factory covered up spoiled meat is as stated in the text, "... how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." Even though the meat is spoiled, the factory comes up with various ways to cover it up such as using chemicals or soda to rub it against the meat to avoid suspicions.

When the text says "There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white."This proves that there was many things in this meat that wasnt readable and shouldnt have been sold.

The Chicago meatpacking industry was exposed for public distribution of spoiled meat that was altered to look like regular meat by using chemistry and mixtures. For example, if meat is discovered to be sour after being taken from the pickle, it is rubbed with soda to take the smell away. Chemistry was also practiced to choose the color, flavor, and odor of the ruined meat (paragraph 2). This meant that to successfully cover up the sanitary meat sold to the public, chemistry was practiced to make it look healthy. In addition, chemical combinations, such as borax and glycerin, were added to spoiled meat and dumped back into the hopper to be sold to the public (paragraph 3). They were able to not only preserve the moldy meat with borax, but also mixed it in with fresh meats to cover up the taste or smell of spoiled meat. Upton Sinclair was able to expose the meatpacking industry for using chemistry and mixtures to cover up the spoiled meat that was reused and sold to the public.

The factory depicted by Upton Sinclair used various ways to use or cover up spoiled meat such as filling the ham with pickle juice,  and replacing spoiled bones with hot irons. For example, "saved time and increased the capacity of the plant—a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds."(Sinclair 2). Machinery was used to inject the spoiled hams with pickle juice in order to save money. The pickle juice was used to mask the smell and taste of spoiled meat to make the factory more money for less effort. Another example of the factories's methods is "extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron."(Sinclair 2). A new device was invented that could remove the contaminated bones of the meat that lowered the quality. The bone was replaced with iron, so the factory could make more money selling "higher quality" meat products. That is how the factory in The Jungle  used  wicked means to cover up and sell spoiled meat at the public's expense to make more profit.

(Sinclair 2).

¨Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. In the pickling of hams, they had an ingenious apparatus,1 by which they saved time and increased the capacity2 of the plant—a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with a pickle in a few seconds. The factory took advantage of packaging. The text states, " To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as “giving them thirty per cent.” Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as “Number Three Grade,” but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade. The packers were always originating such schemes—they had what they called “boneless hams,” which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and “California hams,” which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy “skinned hams,” which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them—that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled “head cheese!”

It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white—it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption. There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together.
