There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white—it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption. There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together.

The factory would often use methods such as chemicals to attempt to neutralize the smell of the spoiled meat, or a stronger pickle to put in the hams to destroy the odor. Some people would extract the bone from where the bad smell was located and it usually killed of the scent, " And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as “giving them thirty per cent.” Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as “Number Three Grade,” but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade. The packers were always originating such schemes—they had what they called “boneless hams,” which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; "(The Jungle).

The 2 ways that it says it covers up the smell are putting a pickle mixture in the meat. And it also says that they used a hot iron swell. I know this because in paragraph 2 it says "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus, by which they saved time and increased the capacity of the plant—a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds.  Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as “Number Three Grade,” but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron."

The factory uses spoiled meat in various ways.  For example, they use it in their sausages: "For it was the custom, as [the workers] found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage" (Sinclair, paragraph 1).  Some, however, are so spoiled that the odor drives the workers away, with unfortunate consequences: "And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty per cent [sic].' Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad [sic]" (Sinclair, paragraph 2).  Sometimes, to add salt to the wound, the factory would add dangerous chemicals to the spoiled meat: "[the spoiled meat] would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption" (Sinclair, paragraph 3).  Worse yet, they were to be eaten.  Disgusting!

The factory used various ways to use and cover up spoiled meat. For example, when the meat would become spoiled they would "rub it up with soda to take away the smell" (Source 1). They used this in order to continue selling this spoiled meat despite the fact that it was unhealthy. The factory would just take away the smell to cover up the fact that it was old. Continuing, whenever Europe would send back "old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin" (Source 1) so that it could be sent back out. They ensured that they weren't losing money on this dirty, old sausage. By using chemicals they could still use the spoiled meat. Moreover, the factory stored barrels and "the barrels would be dirt and rust and old nails and stale water – and cartload after cartload of it would be taken up and dumped into the hoppers with fresh meat" (Source 1). This would happen once a year, meaning this meat and grime would sit for a year and then they would sell it to the people. They didn't care about anything but getting the money from this sailed meat. The factory would do anything and put any chemical or trick on the meat in order to use or cover up the spoiled meat.

The meat factory chops spoiled meat into sausages, run the spoiled meat up with soda so it wouldn't smell, put chemicals into food to make it any odor or taste they want, put pickles inside meat to stop them from smelling,  dosed old sausage with borax and glycerin, and used many other methods so that they could sell the spoiled meat. In the text it states, "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage." They chopped up spoiled meat into sausages so that they could still be eaten. Based on the reading, "... how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." This text evidence tells us that meat was often played with and chemicals were often poured into it so that workers could stop it from smelling and make it be able to be sold again. In conclusions, the meat industry used  many methods so that they didn't have to sell fresh meat, so that they could keep selling spoiled meat.

To cover up the spoiled meat the factory would rub it with soda and they would use chemistry to give the meat any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. (paragraph 2).  Man would fill ham with pickle. In the text it also says that "they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. " The packers would also give the meat fancy names such as "boneless hams" "california hams"  "skinned hams"  and "head cheese". In paragraph 3 it states that "when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat." In paragraph 3 it also says that old sausage that was rejected and that was moldy and white would be dosed with borax and glycerin and dumped into hoppers and made over again for home consumption. In paragraph 4 it says that they would make the meat into "smoked" sausage. They would also preserve the meat with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown. In paragraph 5 it says that the packers would stamp some of the meat as "special". These were the ways that the factory would cover up spoiled meat.

The factory is an environment that is unsafe due to its repulsive conditions and practices. Those factors are what caused the meat to be spoiled and contaminated. But regardless of the hazardous conditions, the meat had gone under, the factory still had to make a profit. One of the ways the spoiled meat was covered up was a process in which the bone was removed and in place would be a hot iron. "but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white hot-iron" (paragraph 2).  The bone needed to be removed from the spoiled meat since that is mainly where the spoiledness would be located. Another way the spoiled meat would be preserved is in a casing. "...all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings" (Paragraph 2). Every piece of the spoiled ham would be put into a casing in which the factory would market it as a "boneless ham" (paragraph 2).  One more way the spoiled meat was concealed is by altering its scent and appearance. "... and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown" (paragraph 5). The spoiled meat would be maintained because of the ingredient borax while the gelatin would change the ticketing features of the meat.

The meatpacking factory had found many solutions to use or cover up spoiled meat. For instance, when meat that was taken out of pickle was "found sour," instead of scrapping the meat, the company decided to "...rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free lunch counters" (Sinclair). In addition, when hams that were pickled were found spoiled, some of them with, "...an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them," (Sinclair), a second pickle would instead be pumped into the same meat, which destroyed the odor. This process, so often used in the meatpacking industry, became known to the workers as "giving them thirty per cent" (Sinclair). Lastly,  the industry would label products after working on the meat to make the odor, bacteria, or old parts of the meat go away, creating products such as "boneless hams", which were "odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings," or even "skinned hams," labeled as fancy, which were made of the oldest pigs, with heavy and coarse skin, "...that no one would buy-that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled "head cheese!"" (Sinclair).

In the meatpacking industry, the workers would use certain methods, such as taking the bones out of rotten ham or pickling the ham to reduce the odor.  Sinclair states that "some ingenious person had hit upon a new device" where they would "extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay" in order to get rid of grades for the meats (Sinclair 2). Even though a bad part of the meat was being extracted, the way it was done was still sanitary and it was used as a scheme by the meatpacking industry to appeal to the greater population. The meatpacking industry found another way to increase productivity by "fill[ing] a ham with pickle in a few seconds" through the process of using a "needle into the meat and working with his foot" in order to make the meat last longer, even at the cost of ruining its sanitation (Sinclair 2). The fact that the workers would use their feet in the process indicated how the meatpacking industry was corrupt when it came to providing sanitary ham's to the population and that it would find any way possible to increase productivity and cover-up spoiled meat. In Excerpt From The Jungle by Upton Sinclair, light is shed on the corrupt practices of the meat industry as they would taken the bones out of rotten ham and pickle ham to reduce the odor in attempts to cover it up from the rest of the population.

In paragraph 2, it states that "the meat was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell". This was one of the ways in which the factory would cover up spoiled meat, because they would attempt to disguise the smell of the meat. In paragraph 3 it states "when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference". This shows yet another way in which the factory would use spoiled meat, by cutting it up so that fresh meat could be mixed with a small amount of the spoiled meat, thus discussing the spoiled meat. In paragraph 4, it also states that "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it". This quote demonstrates how the factory would use meat that is being contaminated by the factory conditions and habits. However, this meat was continued to be used to sell in the future.

They did various things with spoiled meat. They would can it or chop it into sausage if it wasn't too spoiled. If they took it out of the pickle and it was sour they would rub it with soda to take the smell away and sell it. When they used the machine to pickle the ham there were still some that came out sour. Some of them were too sour to stand. Then they would pump the sour ham with an even stronger pickle that got rid of the smell. For the hams, they would stuff odds and ends of pork into casings. California hams were shoulders, knuckle joints, and most of the meat cut out. The skinned hams were old hogs that were tough and no one bought until it was cooked and chopped to be head cheese. When the whole ham was spoiled they mixed it with good meat and canned.  The moldy sausage that came from  Europe was dosed with borax and glycerin. They sent it out to shops again.  Poisoned rats went in the sausage along with the spoiled chopped up meat. The waste barrels were cleaned out once in a while and mixed with fresh meat to go to shops.  Some of it would be made into smoked sausage. They would rub it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it look brown and sell it. All of these methods were disgusting. You never knew what you were going to get. It was a pork surprise.

There were various things that the factory would do to cover up and essentially use the spoiled meat that they had. One manner in which they practiced this was by rubbing the meat with soda to take away the smell, as stated in paragraph two.  The workers would also pickle their meat to get rid of the odor but if it was very urgent, they had a second and much stronger pickle which helped destroy the smell, which the workers called, "giving them thirty per cent." Along with this, they would label the packages in many ways to make it look like it was "original" even if they were made out of meat parts that were not supposed to be used. Another form in which they would use and cover-up spoiled meat would be by getting spoiled whole ham and old sausage with mold from Europe and losing it with borax and glycerin, where it would then be dumped into hoppers and made over again for packaging. Mice, feces, poisoned bread, dirt, diseases, and sawdust were just a few things that would be processed in the hoppers along with the spoiled meat. Lastly, they would also use their chemistry department to make sausages appear brown-with the use of borax and colored gelatin- and labeled it "smoked" sausage after their practice of smoking sausage became expensive for the factory.  In all, the actions in which the factory practiced were extremely sanitary and do not appear today thanks to the Meat Inspection Act.

In order to cover up spoiled meat, the factory would do the bare minimum. In the second paragraph, it says "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty percent.'" These factories would put spoiled meat products in with fresh products to level it out and help them go unnoticed. These factories would also take out parts of the ham to reveal it at top value. Also in the second paragraph, it says "later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade." By making meats boneless these companies and factories would be able to avoid the bad quality labels and would be able to get away with a possibly dangerous health risk.  These factories would grind up meats and animal products that had gone bad in order to support the high demand and save money, despite the potential harm that this process has on customers. This can be supported by a sentence in the third paragraph that says "Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference."

With the help of Sinclair and Jonas, the shameful conditions that once occurred in Chicago's meatpacking industry had been caught. Specifically, Sinclair reveals the immoral actions that transpired in an attempt to cover up spoiled meat.  Sinclair indicates that the factories covered up spoiled meat through masking doors, refusing rejected meat, and combining normal meat and rat meat simply out of pure laziness. For example, Sinclair states that the meat "would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." That quote in itself explains one of the many attempts in which the factories hid their corrupt techniques. Additionally, Sinclair incorporates vivid and descriptive imagery to illustrate the masked meatpacking process. Sinclair states, "There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms, and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats." The explanation regarding the rats and the leaky rooms emphasizes the feeble conditions located in the specific offices. Another way in which the factory workers hid their spoiled meat was by supplementing porous pickles to the most spoiled portions of meat. This was done in an attempt to mask the speech of the meat. Overall, Sinclair uses tone and imagery to illustrate the corrupt business done by meatpacking workers.

The meatpacking industry came up with many creative ways to hide the fact their meat was spoiled. One way is that they would simply just chop it up and use it for sausage, ¨whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage¨ (Sinclair 1). If the meat was so gross and spoiled that it could not be used for anything else they would just use it, along with any other meat they could not use, for sausage. For meat that was spoiled that only had a smell, they would use chemicals or soda to cover the smell, ¨they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell¨ (Sinclair 2). Another way to cover the small was to sell it as pickled meat, ¨the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor¨ (Sinclair 2). A lot of the meatpacking industries would send their meat to other countries like Europe to be sold there, some places in Europe would have to send it back because the meat was too old and spoiled. When this happened all the packing industries would load it with chemicals to be sent back, ¨it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption¨ (Sinclair 3). This shows how poorly the meatpacking business takes care of their work environment and how much they do not care about the people who consume their products.

The excerpt describes many ways that the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat. " the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose."   Furthermore,  the author states that there were various ways that each part of a pig was covered-up after spelling but after the whole pig was spoiled, it was all used for sausage. The factories would use various ways to cover up spoiled meat. [2] This quote explains how even when the meat had become sour and smells, the factory would use methods like rubbing soda on it and chemical altering the meat. The  meat factory is terrible because they would take spoiled meat and mix it with regular meat and sell it. It's unhealthy and unsafe, people could get sick or get a disease that could kill them.  According to the text," whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage. This just explains what they did with the spoiled meat and how they still sold it. The smell was so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. They pumped the meat into these packers to destroy the odor. In the text, it states, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose."This tells you how they pumped the meat and destroyed the odor. In conclusion, the meat factory was not taking care of the meat properly and could have started a disease or got someone sick.

The various ways the factory could use or cover up spoiled meat include mixing it with fish meat, housing it in chemicals, or just mixing anything and everything together to make sausages. "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage."(1) One way they cover up spoiled meat is to chop it up and mix it with other meat so that it can't be seen that it's spoiled Another of many ways the factories can secretly use spoiled meat in their products is by housing it with chemicals to make it appear fresh, "...also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. " This quotes shares how the factories can simply make any meat look good no matter how old or molded it is. A third way that the factories can use spoiled meat is by making it into sausages, "There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption."(3) The repulsive truth behind the making of sausages is explained in this quote, also adding to the explanation of the factories simply covering their products in chemicals to sell again.

Upton Sinclair strengthens his argument that conditions were sanitary in meat processing factories through describing the various ways in which workers would use or cover up spoiled meat. This included suppressing the odor through the use of borax and glycerin, adding more meat to cover the spoiled meat, filling hams with pickle, chopping spoiled meat to make "sausage", selling bad hams as "Number Three Grade", and through extracting the bone of bad ham and selling it as boneless ham. Since spoiled meat had a very strong odor to it, workers within factories had to ensure that consumers would not be able to smell it so that they would be more likely to buy and consume it. As a result, they used sweet smelling or colorless products in order to mask the speech. Hams were pickled with a machine that was both quick and effective, but would sometimes spoil the meat further. This detail further helped to support Sinclair's claim that factories mainly cared about making a profit rather than the health of their consumers. Additionally, factory workers used methods of hiding or covering up spoiled meat by making it more subtle through covering it with spoiled meat or chopping it into smaller pieces so it would go unnoticed by consumers. Lastly, Sinclair describes how spoiled ham was especially covered up through selling bad ham as "Number Three Grade" or "smoked ham". Later however, "they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron" (Sinclair 1906). This would eliminate the title of "Number Three Grade" in favor of "boneless ham".

In the excerpt from the 1906 novel,"The Jungle" by Upton Sinclair, it states the various ways the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat. In the text it states, " Jonas told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed..." (Sinclair par.2).  From the text it's shown that the workers would use baking soda to take away the strong odor of the sour meat, and even used chemistry to give it a more fresh taste and odor. This method saved the company money, but was wrong because it was selling people spoiled meat that could possibly make them sick. In paragraph 2 it also states, "... some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle with destroyed the odor--a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty percent'" (Sinclair par.2). When the speech from the meat was bad enough workers would also use a machine to fill the meat with pickle to help rid of the doors. They would use much stronger pickle, and still end up selling the spoiled meat. In the end, the ways they would cover up the spoiled meat is by using baking soda, pickle, or chemistry to help rid of the doors to sell spoiled meat to consumers.

The factory would often mask the smell of the spoiled meat by "giving them thirty percent", which used a pump that was stronger than usual to destroy the smell. They would also rub soda on the meat at times to take away the spoiled smell, Sinclair says, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters." Another way they would cover up spoiled meat would be taking the bone out and replacing it with a white-iron rod, as Sinclair states, "after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad... they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron", and then they would label these as "boneless hams", getting rid of the three level grading scale. In order to cover up spoiled meat, the factory would also just mix it in with non spoiled meat, to make it look like they had used one-hundred percent non spoiled meat. The factory would also take in old sausage that had been rejected and use chemicals to mask the spoilage, and then reuse it, Sinclair goes more in depth when he says, "there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption."

The Factory would use various ways to cover up spoiled meat. One of the ways they would cover it up is by chopping it up into sausage.  The narrator says, "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage. " (Sinclair 1). Another way the factory would cover up the spoilt meat was, "the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell..." (Sinclair 2). Jonas, a person who had worked in the factory told them they would do this instead of throwing the meat away. The factory would also cut up the moldy meat, meat dropped on the floor, rats, and other going bad foods, put them into the hoppers and made over again to sell.  Finally, the narrator says, "Some of it they would make into "smoked" sausage – but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown. All of their sausage came out of the same bowl, but when they came to wrap it they would stamp some of it "special," and for this they would charge two cents more a pound." The factory would mix everything together and sell for a higher price, tracking the people into believing that it was a higher ranked meat. This is all of the ways that the factory would cover up the spoiled meat.

Meat bothering factories used many different sanitary and unlawful practices to cover up spoiled meat. Factories used spoiled meat in sausage as the smell wouldnt be affected greatly becuase of the quantity of meat being ground. Factories used soda to rub away the smell of rot o meats. Factories also filled hams with pickle to make them stop smelling. Factories also extracted the bones and inserted burning hot metal rods into meat to burn away the most dotted parts of the meat. I know this becuase the text says this, " the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell ...  a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor...Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as “Number Three Grade,” but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade. The packers were always originating such schemes"

The factories would do many things to make money of rcid meat. One thing they would do is mix the sour meat withthe good meat to make sausages.  "There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." (paragraph 3) Additionally, there were a lot of chemicals put in the meat to make it look and smell fresh, but in reality it was not. " the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." (paragraph 1) The storage of meat was also unacceptable, meat was just laying around aimlessly. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats." (paragraph 4)

There was various ways the factory would use and cover up spoiled meat. One way the factory did this in the beginning was by chopping it up and making it into sausage. In the text it says the meat couldn't be used for anything else so sausage was their last resort. Another way they covered up spoiled meat was by using chemicals. In the text it says "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pile would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." This goes to show chemicals played a role in the process, but not only did they make it into sausage and use chemicals, they also would pump the meat. Over time the factory gained control over a second pickle one much stronger than the first and this one got rid of the odor of the meat completely making the price rise thory cents because the meat didn't smell. Although the meat was already contaminated and spoiled enough, they even furthered and used the skin of the oldest hogs. There are various ways that they had covered up the spoiled meet. One of those ways is that the spoiled meat that was not picked or taken out of the pickle would be covered with soda to take away to smell. Evidence to support this is, "Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters;" Another way they covered up spoiled meat was that they pumped much stronger pickle into the ham to destroy the oder of the spoiled meat. "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty per cent.'" Also, another way is they would take out the bone where the bad part is and insert a white-hot iron into the ham. Proof of this is, "Formerly these had been sold as “Number Three Grade,” but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron." A fourth way they would do this is that they would cut the meat up and mix it with a half a ton of other meat, send it all the way back to Europe where they covered it with borax and glycerin and made it all over again  for home consumption. Evidence of this is, "it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." This all shows how they would cover up spoiled meat and sell it to people without worrying if it would make them sick.

The factories would use products such as borax, glycerin, and soda to mask the smell and moldy sausages.  "there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." (3) Sinclair explains that these factories are willing to risk the health of many human beings for some more money. Not only are the factories willing to do this but the employees swell.  Looking at this question of whether or not to use supplies to contaminated meat seems like a very simple answer. However, to the factory workers in the twentieth century, it was not. Not only was it not a simple answer there was no question.  "There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it ... . It was too dark in these storage places to see well ... There was no place for the men to wash their hands before they ate their dinner" (4-5) Sinclair goes on to explain that there was not an option for the workers, and the factory owners knew this.  They knew the workers needed the money to provide for their families.  To add to the atmosphere of the factories Sinclair says, "With one member trimming beef in a cannery, and another working in a sausage factory, the family had a first-hand knowledge" (1) The people were scared to step up for fear of backlash from their "family".   This is another example of things that factory owners used to control and cover up spoiled meat.  Using supplies such as borax, glycerin, and soda and creating a toxic work environment are two examples of methods factories used to cover up spoiled meat.

The factory would use a variety of ways to cover up the spoiled meat. First, when the meat came out of pickle it would be sour so they would rub it with soda to get rid of the smell to be able to sell it. They would also perform any "miracle" of chemistry, "giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose" (Sinclair p 2). To save time and increase their capacity, they used a machine that would be able to pickle a ham in a few seconds, but would sometimes leave the hams spoiled with a disgusting odor. To solve this issue, the packers used a stronger pickle. After smoking the hams, some would be found to have gone bad but were still sold to the public as "Number Three Grade". To solve this problem, they decided to extract the bone and insert a white-hot iron, getting rid of all but Number One Grade. To be able to keep selling to the general public, the packers made up numerous schemes and "they had what they called 'boneless hams,' which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and 'California hams,' which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy 'skinned hams,' which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no  one would buy them--that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled 'head cheese!'" (Sinclair p 2). When the whole ham was spoiled, it went to another department where they would mix it with half a ton of other meat, even if the other meat was moldy and white, and then it would be dosed with borax and glycerin.

Factories used various methods to use or cover up spoiled meat during the gilded age some of these methods include, "they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown. "All of their sausage came out of the same bowl, but when they came to wrap it they would stamp some of it 'special,' and for this they would charge two cents more a pound." This was not only disgusting, it was also dangerous as these chemicals could harm you and even cause death. "In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus, by which they saved time and increased the capacity of the plant—a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty per cent." "Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as 'Number Three Grade,' but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade." This was disgusting as what should've been qualified as "Number Three Grade" which meant that the meat had gone bad was instead qualified as a "Number One Grade" even though the meat was bad and dangerous.

There are plenty of ways that this factory would cover up spoiled meat. One way was by using the spoiled meat, housing it in chemicals, and packaging it, and selling it to their consumers. The sausage, "...was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption" (Sinclair 3). This factory was only focused on making as much money as possible by, "...stamping some of it "special," and for this they would charge two cents more a pound" (Sinclair 5) and not caring about the cleanliness or literal hazard that selling this sausage was. Additionally, other conditions were that, "...there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them"(Sinclair 2). To cover this issue up, they would rub code on the meat to try to deordorize it. Yet, that not working shows how gross the meat really was. The workers did not wash their hands- they did not even have the ability to do so, and they spit all over the food. There was absolutely no sense of sterilization as, "...making a practice of washing them in the water that was to be ladled into the sausage. There were the butt-ends of smoked meat, and the scraps of corned beef, and all the odds and ends of the waste of the plants, that would be dumped into old barrels in the cellar and left there" (Sinclair 5). To cover this up, they would trick their consumers and re-color the meat with broad and gelatin to make it look a presentable color. Their main goal was to obtain more profit; the factory used and re-used disgusting, ticketing, spoiled meat and sold it like there was no issue with it.

The Jungle by Upton Sinclair explains several processes by which violations of the meatpacking happened. Meat factory workers would prepare rotten and diseased meat with better meats. The unpleasant pork fat and beef scraps will be packed or canned like chicken. Many of these meats would be chopped up to make sausage. "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage." (Paragraph 1, lines 5-7).  "It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." (Paragraph 3, lines 34-39). "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms, and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together. " (Paragraph 4, lines 40-45).

This contributes to how the factor would cover up spoiled meat because they put their workers through various vigorous processes in order to make the meat up to standard to sell. " This quote explains how now the factory was finding loopholes in order to salvage spoiled meat any way possible. This connects with ho the factory tried to cover up spoiled meat because now they would insert a hot iron to get ride of the bone that had gone bad, and that would eliminate the grading system. One way the factory would cover up spoiled meat odor was by pickling the hams that were spoiled, and if the meat managed to stink again they would be pickled once more with a stronger solution and sold to the public. There are so many different ways they would cover things up, I've honestly lost count. One technique used is found in Paragraph 2, where the story states that, "In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus,1 by which they saved time and increased the capacity of the plant—a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds." This small section shows that they tried to mask the rotting smell with pickle juice. However, the story goes on to say that failed. Paragraph 4 also shows the true nature of these factories, saying, "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together. This is no fairy story and no joke; the meat would be shoveled into carts, and the man who did the shoveling would not trouble to lift out a rat even when he saw one – there were things that went into the sausage in comparison with which a poisoned rat was a tidbit." Just imagine getting all of those germs served on your plate for breakfast. The idea is nauseating. Sanitary animals would poop on the already dirty meat, only for men to wipe their dirty hands across it. What would be the final product? A rat and poop, poisoned bread, dirty water, filthy hand, rotting meat connection. This is utterly disgusting and may have just ruined ham for me.

And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as “giving them thirty per cent.” Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as “Number Three Grade,” but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade. The packers were always originating such schemes—they had what they called “boneless hams,” which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and “California hams,” which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy “skinned hams,” which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them—that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled “head cheese!”

There were many ways the factory would use to hinder the condition of the spoiled meat. One of the various ways the factory would cover up spoiled meat was by rubbing the meat against soda to get rid of the odor. According to lines 19-21, "also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." They used the chemistry in the method of rubbing the meat against the soda to change the appearance and smell of the meat to make it more appetizing however, it hides the true condition of the meat.  Another way the factory covered up the spoiled meat was incorporating glycerin and borax from sausage rejected from Europe-suggesting the conditions of the spoiled meat were noticeable. According to paragraph 3 "it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." Signifying this was a repeated process to get the sausage accepted to other countries.  Furthermore, the factory would hide the spoiled meat by "giving them thirty-percent" which was done prior to finding hams spoiled from injection.  The text states "Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as “Number Three Grade,” but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade." This conveys that the factory narrowed down the techniques used to hinder the spoiled condition of the meat first done by intensifying the amount of pickle to hide the smell to creating devices and apparatus that extracted the "bad parts" (which created the condition) of the meat, in this case the bone. The new name for the meat being Number One Grade. These are the ways the factory was able to hide the state of the spoiled meat for selling.

In the article, Excerpt From The Jungle, there were many ways factories tried to cover up spoiled meat. Throughout this article it tells us that no matter the color, flavor, or smell they would still sell the meat. These factories didn't care for the health of their consumers and only wanted to make money, so they sold every piece of meat that they could. While reading this article it sounds like they would never let a single piece of meat go to waste even if it was spoiled and covered in mold. In the article it states, “old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption.”(3). This quote from the article explains to us how they covered up the molded meat by using strong and toxic chemicals to get rid of the smell and turn the meat back to brown. The factories had no health regulations, the meat was stored in places infested with germs. The factories knew how filthy their facility was and had put no effort in  to change it. In paragraph 4 it states, “There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs.”(4). This tells us how nobody cared about the condition the meat was in and how no one enforced them to follow any guidelines that had been put in place. Workers knew that what they were doing was wrong and never second guessed it, “a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together.”(4). This quote from the article tells the reader how they used rat meat for sausages. These rats contained many diseases and carried poison from eating contaminated  bread. Which they thought was right to feed  humans. In the factories, spoiled meat was covered up badly. Instead of throwing away the rotting meat they found ways to use it to seem constable to humanity while they were making it much worse.

There were various ways that factories would use or cover up spoiled meat. The employees played a huge role in why meat was processed under harsh conditions. Workers lacked washing their hands, and the water that men washed their hands in was also ladled into sausages. Meat would be tumbled out on the floor in dust and dirt. Meat would fall onto surfaces where employees have spit thousand of times. As a result of this, meats were extremely treacherous. According to the text, it states, "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs." The meat was also in a space where rats were present, causing rats to run across the meats. As a result of rats running around, they poison them. After poisoning the rats, the rats would go in the hopper with the meat while they are processing. Workers call the poisoned rat a tidbit, and they did not care to remove the rat from the meat. This was extremely sanitary and cruel. According to the text, it states, "There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms, and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it." Workers were also capable of changing the meat into; however, they wanted them, such as turning the meat brown or making the meat "spoil." They would use chemistry and machines to change spoiled meat. If it were so difficult to get these meats to change, they would sell it as a number three grade meat. According to the text, it states, "Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as "Number Three Grade," but later on, some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron." The workers also rubbed meat in soda to get meat to go from sour to sweet and change the bad odor. After doing this, they would provide it to people over the free lunch counter. These conditions were very harsh, but workers did not care about receiving the public; they only wanted money.

The packers were always originating such schemes—they had what they called “boneless hams,” which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and “California hams,” which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy “skinned hams,” which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them—that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled 'head cheese!'" This quote proves that they used these methods to cover up spoiled meat.

The meatpacking houses would disguise the taste, smell, color, and presentation of the meat to cover up the fact that it was spoiled. Sinclair describes the process from the word of a pickle room worker, "... the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. " (Paragraph 2).  He goes on to explain that they still worked with meat that had an unbearable smell to the workers and they would just pickle the meat stronger to destroy the oder. He also added that The meatpacking houses would disguise the taste, smell, color, and presentation of the meat to cover up the fact that it was spoiled. Sinclair describes the process from the word of a pickle room worker, "... the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. " (Paragraph 2).  He goes on to explain that they still worked with meat that had an unbearable smell and they would just pickle the meat stronger to destroy the oder. He also added that that some spoiled meat that contained white coloring and mold would be used for sausages and home consumption.  Sinclair starts to  explain the sausage process, "Some of it they would make into "smoked" sausage – but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown. " (Paragraph 5).  He proceeds to state that all the sausages were the same but some were gabled differently to increase the price.  He also adds that no one pays attention to what goes in the sausage as long as its made. The meatpacking houses wrongly hid the condition of the meat by altering the taste with stronger pickling, smell by rubbing it with soda, color by using different chemicals that were unhealthy, and presentation by either grinding it, hoping it, or whatever else was acceptable.

The first way the factory would cover up spoiled meat was to put it in sausage. In paragraph one the author writes, "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever year was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage." This explains how they would put spoiled meat with fresh meat, instead of throwing the spoiled meat out. If the factory didn't put the spoiled meat in sausage, they would rub it with soda to take away the small, or they would use chemicals to enhance aspects of the meat. From paragraph two it states, "...how the meat that was taken our of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose." This explains there use of soda and chemicals to mask the spoiled meat. Next up, the factory would stuff ham with the spoiled meat using a machine and a needle. The text explains in paragraph two, "... a caching consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled..." This evidence further describes how they would mask spoiled meat. Finally, once the factory discovered how to take the bone out of a ham, they would insert a white-hot iron, and they would go on to sell "boneless hams" or "California hams" and fancy "skinned hams" which all were filled with spoiled meat. However no one would buy skinned hams, until they were cooked, and chopped up fine, which they then called "head cheese". Evidence comes from paragraph two, "...but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. The packers were always originating such schemes—they had what they called “boneless hams,” which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and “California hams,” which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy “skinned hams,” which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them—that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled “head cheese!” These lines of text explain the procedure that happened to the hams just for them to be sold. The experiment took place at Cubberley High School in Polo Alto, California, during the first week of April 1967. Jones, finding himself unable to explain to his students how the German population could have claimed ignorance of The Holocaust, decided to demonstrate it to them instead.  Jones started a movement called «The Third Wave» and told his students that the movement aimed to eliminate democracy.  Jones himself wrote a detailed account of the experiment some nine years afterward and more articles about the experiment followed, including some interviews with Jones and the original students.

The Third Wave experiment took place at Cubberley High School in Polo Alto, California during the first week of April 1967. History teacher Ron Jones, finding himself unable to explain to his students how people throughout history followed the crowd even when terrible things were happening, decided to demonstrate it to his students through an experiment. Jones announced that he was starting a movement aimed to eliminate democracy. Jones named the movement “The Third Wave” as a symbol of strength, referring to the mythical belief that the third in a series of waves is the strongest.

The Third Wave developed quickly over a short amount of time because the kids that had participated took it very seriously. The kids also had started to show their devotion to the cause by salting to each other making the other kids think that they needed to get in on it. The narrator says ¨Jones made up a salute resembling that of the Nazi regime and ordered class members to salute each other even outside the class. They all obeyed this command¨(paragraph 1). Right after the kids had been doing this the next day they had more participants.

The third wave developed over such a short period of time because all the kids enjoyed being involved in the movement. "Strength through discipline, strength through community, strength through action, strength through pride." This motto was very catchy and all the students enjoyed saying it. They were all very involved and this was when Mr. Jones decided it was time the experiment was ended. The students would report to him when other members failed to abide by the rules and they were all too involved. He knew that it was time for the experiment to be finished.

The Third Wave was developed over a short time because Ron Jones originally wanted to make an experiment to symbolize strength among his students.  After over 200 students became increasingly involved with the project, he decided that it was slipping out of control and he had to put an end to it.  Jones told his students that they "had been a part of an experiment to demonstrate how people willingly create a sense of superiority over others, and how this can lead people to justify doing horrible things in the name of the state’s honor." (Paragraph 5)

The Third Wave developed so quickly because of the convincing way he phrased his experiment and the actions he did to carry out his experiment. First, he started off with a motto that was easy to remember and catchy to say. He then took actions to enforce disciplines into his students, even making them use the salute to fellow students outside of class. The students complied because and because they were so easily molded to Ron Jones' ideas. It was ended because it became clear that the students were becoming too reliable and there was no point in doing the experiment anymore.

The Third Wave developed quickly due to students believing in its "strength," and students on the outside seeing their peers within the Wave as successful and leading. The salute also assisted in this endeavor, as it served as a way for Wave members to connect outside of class, and peers to see it throughout the school. The students were proud to see their strength in numbers and success in the movement through bandwagon. The experiment was ended because Jones had seen it slipping out of control due to the students' loyalty to the movement, as well as their control.

The Third Wave experiment took place at Cubberley High School in Polo Alto, California during the first week of April 1967. Jones started the first day of the experiment emphasizing simple things like proper seating, and drilled the students extensively until they got it right. After only three days, the experiment took on a life of its own, with students from all over the school joining in. By the fourth day of the experiment, the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control. At the end of the week, instead of a televised address of their leader, the students were presented with a blank channel.

The Third Wave developed over such a short period of time because Ron Jones, a history teacher at Cubberley High School, conducted an experiment on his students to teach them about German mentality. Jones established rules in his classroom and developed an authoritative dictatorship to enforce his students to behave in a more orderly way. As once student began changing their actions and behaviors, all other students quickly joined.  When the fourth day of the experiment came along, Jones felt as if he was looking control of his students. This was because their involvement in the experiment was increasing and their loyalty, as well as discipline was becoming too much. As a result, Jones decided it was best if he just terminated the entire experiment.

The Project expanded from originally 30 students to 200. At the start, the students did academically well and were even more motivated. By the fourth day, the students were so involved and their discipline was so good that Jones felt like it was going out of control. More and more students were joining, and the students would do bad things like copying the Nazi salute (just because he did so as part of the experiment), just for the movement. One day he told the students that the project was a movement around the nation and the leader of the movement would announce the existence of it on Th, and when the students came to a noon rally on Friday, they were met with a black screen.

He tricked the students by telling them that there was a presidential candidate that would represent this nationwide movement, and announce it over television. They were shown a blank channel, then they were told about the experiment and what it was about.

Jones created a motto which was, "Strength through discipline, strength through community, strength through action, strength through pride." This gave them a sense of power together and it was something easy to follow. The students began to tell other students about it and Jones had them salute each other outside of class too. The experiment was ended because Jones was afraid it was getting out of hand and it might've turned into something bigger than him that he might not be able to stop.

The Third Wave started as a set of ideas to eliminate democracy for its weakness of focusing only on the individual and a motto. During the first day, the teacher added strict rules and a salute that students were expected to also perform outside of class. Bound up by this sense of discipline and superiority, the students completed their assignments with increasing fervor and began to rope others into it , until it had spread to over 200 people. This experiment was ended after the fifth day, however, because the students were so involved and loyal that the teacher felt that he could no longer control it. As the entire project was based off of the effects of authoritarian regimes, it definitely wasn't something that should be left to get out of hand.

The Third Wave, as Ron Jones called it, was meant to be a simple social experiment focused only on his class of 30 students. The Third Wave gained followers and strength so quickly most likely due to the securities of high school students. All that teenagers want is to fit in and be included. So when students began to see Jones' kids doing their exclusive salute in the halls, they would feel left out. This insecurity along with natural herd behavior of humans, would cause the kids to want to join the group. However, after just five days, the experiment needed to end.  The students had taken too much pride and were too involved in The Third Wave for it to continue without the students giving up all sense of identity.

The Third Wave experiment was initially formed to demonstrate to students how all throughout history, people have been following the crowd and don't stop even though wrong is being done. This experiment was short-lived as it was all too successful. As students saw others conforming to Mr. Jones' commands, they soon followed suit because of the shear fact that they wanted to fit in. Then this became a formality to the students and they became dedicated to it, this was a constant in their life, so it could've been conforming. The students though started to get increasingly involved in it by the fourth day, and began to slip out of control. Then for this reason, it was ended after Jones told them of the experiment.

The Third Wave developed over such a short period of time because the students were following the leader that they grew to trust and they followed each other in herd like behavior. Over that short period of time, Mr. Jones demonstrated how quickly and effectively he could get that group of students to obey and listen to him at all costs. The text states, "... they had been a part of an experiment to demonstrate how people willingly create a sense of superiority over others, and how this can lead people to justify doing horrible things in the name of the state’s honor." This example shows how the students felt that since they were apart of a group, they were above anyone else who wasn't in the 
 specific group.

The third wave was an experiment developed by Ron Jones, a high school teacher at Cubberley High School in Polo Alto, California in 1969. The experiment was a demonstration of how democratic states are not usually protected by the influence of fascism which is the belief in absolute control of all people by a single dictator.  Ron developed an authoritative dictatorship in the classroom to teach students the German mentality. He established rules such as students should stand up when asking or answering questions in three words, students salting each other similar to that of the Nazi at school and even outside of school. On the fourth day, Ron ended the experiment when he realized that it was slipping out of his control. The students had become extremely involved in the project with high discipline and loyalty to the project.

The Third Wave was an experiment created by high school teacher Ron Jones in 1967 as a way to demonstrate how people would follow the crowd even when bad things resulted from it. The experiment began in Ron's classroom, with a central goal, rules, motto, and even a salute the students were required to use even outside of class. All the students did as they were told, and more and more students around the school joined in on the movement, ending up with over 200 members. Because the students were so loyal to the experiment, Ron felt it had gotten out of hand, and ended it by the end of the week, saying in his announcement that, "...they had been part of an experiment to demonstrate how people willingly create a sense of superiority over others, and how this can lead people to justify doing horrible things in the name of the state's honor." Because the experiment was ultimately a demonstration of human nature, it was able to spread far throughout the school within a very short amount of time.

Jones wasn't aware that his experiment would be so large in the end, he didn't expect so much out of it.  It started off simple and only a few people.  However as a few days went by it went from 30 to 200 people in a quick amount of time.  All of these people listened to Jones and did exactly what he said and they weren't exactly thinking much of it.  When he introduced the salute signal non of the students said no to it and they all did it, "Jones made up a salute resembling that of the Nazi regime and ordered class members to salute each other even outside the class.  They all obeyed this command." Clearly they replicated what occured with the Nazis without even knowing they were doing it.  This shows how out of hand the experiment got and it could have gotten worse if it was continued.  However Jones thought it was appropriate to end the experiment.  This was because it proved his point of how people willingly create superiority and sometimes without even knowing which could lead to bad things.

The third wave developed so quickly because it was fun for the kids it says this in the 3rd paragraph that, After only three days, the experiment took on a life of its own, with students from all over the school joining in. The class expanded from initial 30 students to 43 attendees. All of the students showed drastic improvement in their academic skills and tremendous3 motivation. All of the students were issued a member card and each of them received a special assignment, like designing a Third Wave Banner, stopping non-members from entering the class, or other tasks to bring honor to the movement. Jones instructed the students on how to initiate new members, and by the end of the day the movement had over 200 participants. Jones was surprised that some of the students started reporting to him when other members of the movement failed to abide by the rules. The movement was terminated because the kids were going very far and the students were becoming increasingly involved in the project and there discipline and loyalty to the movement was outstanding but becoming out of control.

The Third Wave was developed by Jones who proceeded to enforce strict classroom discipline by emerging as an authoritarian figure. Jones’ class was transformed into a group with a supreme sense of discipline and community. Jones was surprised that some of the students started reporting to him when other members of the movement failed to abide by the rules. The students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control.  He decided to terminate the movement, so he lied to students by announcing that the Third Wave was a part of a nationwide movement and that on the next day a presidential candidate of the movement would publicly announce its existence on television. instead of a televised address of their leader, the students were presented with a blank channel. After a few minutes of waiting, Jones announced that they had been a part of an experiment to demonstrate how people willingly create a sense of superiority over others, and how this can lead people to justify doing horrible things in the name of the state’s honor.

The Third Wave experiment developed quickly over a short period of time, it is stated that "the class expanded from initial 30 students to 43 students,"(the experiment). The class itself grew in numbers, and the students pride and ignorance grew as well, they began to ostrisize anyone who was not apart of their group and kept close to themselves. It is also stated that "As the week went on, Jones' class transformed into a group with a supreme sense of discipline and community,"(the experiment); the students were dedicated and enthusiastic about the group and what they learned through it. The experiment was ended because Jones felt as though it went too far, he felt as though "it was slipping out of control. he decided to terminate the movement...,"(the experiment). The students were initially surprised of the fact that they confirmed into something they never thought they would become, and that is the terrifying part of it all; someone could hurt others just because they blindly followed others actions and opinions.

The Third Wave developed over such a short period of time because of it's appeal to others through a motto, salute, membership card, etc. All other students saw through example how the other members acted and had success which caused them to want to join. In the article it states, "All of the students were issued a member card and each of them received a special assignment, like designing a Third Wave Banner, stopping non-members from entering the class, or other tasks to bring honor to the movement." This supports the fact that all other students who weren't members where intimidated by the members of the Third Wave and also saw the things like the membership card which gave them a reason to join.
