Overall this experiment showed the power of heard behavior and needed to be ended because of the power the movement had.

A history teacher named Ron Jones created an experiment known as the Third Wave. The purpose was to  explain to his students through actions how people tend to follow the crowd even when terrible things were happen. Ron created an authoratian dictatorship type of to teach his students the German mentality. He established many rules as it states in the text, "Jones started the first day of the experiment emphasizing simple things like proper seating, and drilled the students extensively until they got it right. He then proceeded to enforce strict classroom discipline by emerging as an authoritarian." The excitement soon transformed the class into a group with supreme sense of discipline and community. The experiment ended up ending after just 4 days because, "By the fourth day of the experiment, the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control." Essentially he could not control the excitement anymore, the students had ended up becoming way to involved. This goes to show how people can be brainwashed and get manipulated without even knowing it.

The third wave gained a lot of momentum very quickly and had to be ended before it became to big because of the people that the experiment was targeting. Mr. Jones as we know had a group of highschoolers as his test subjects, and this had a very big affect on why the movement was so successful. These teens were so important because they dont have a lot that divides them, they are impressionable, and they don't have anything of their own yet, meaning that they may not be  concerned with the rights of an individual. These traits are so important because it makes it so that the teens won't question the experiment, they won't mind the lack of democracy, and they are easily united under the common goal of strength. With this rapid growth in the organisation the kids were becoming more and more brainwashed because of herd behavior, and the it needed to be ended because something bad could happen. With the groups being so large and brainwashed they may target minorities who arent apart of the wave because theta are different and don't have the same "strength as them".

The Third Wave developed very quickly because of rules and actions that were seen outside of the classroom. When Mr. Jones' started applying rules, it started simply by standing up to ask or answer a question. Soon actions from the experiment were taken outside of the classroom in front of other people. Mr. Jones started to give instructions that had to be followed outside of the class. He transformed the class to be more disciplined and more of a community by,  "resembling that of the Nazi regime and ordered class members to salute each other even outside the class. They all obeyed this command." Other students must have been interested when only a certain amount of them was doing this secret salute. Other students saw this as an opportunity to feel included in the secret salute and everyone started to join.  Once everyone wanted to join the movement got had gotten out of hand. There were over 200 participants that joined. Mr. Jones started to lose control after so many people joined.  The students became so disciplined and loyal to the project the control started slipping away from Jones, and he had to put an end to it.

Over a very short time period, the Third Wave movement spread throughout Cubberley High. During the first day alone, "dramatic improvements to the efficiency, or orderliness, of the class" (CommonLit Staff 1) could be observed. As students in Mr. Jones' class became more serious about the movement and began to participate in actions outside of the classroom for the movement, more students joined in. The article states that "by the end of the day the movement had over 200 participants," (CommonLit Staff 3) when the class originated with only 30 students. Only 4 days into the experiment, Jones noticed that the students had become "increasingly involved in the project" (CommonLit Staff 4), which prompted him to end the experiment. The students had showcased that they were willing to do potentially damaging things in the name of their cause. Jones' was worried that his experiment was slipping out of control due to this demonstration from the students. This experiment showed how willing the crowd is to follow the example of those around them, and how readily they will compromise their morals to show their support.

The Third Wave was an experiment set up by a high school teacher to show his students "how people throughout history followed the crowd even when terrible things were happening" (paragraph 1). However, Mr. Jones told the students that it was a movement aimed to eliminate democracy, and "that democracy’s main weakness is that it favors the individual over the whole community" (paragraph 1). Jones forced conformity among the students by drilling things like proper seating and emerging as an authoritarian figure. It was meant to be a one-day experiment, but it ended up lasting a whole week. Jones made up a salute resembling the Nazis and ordered the students to salute to each other even outside of class. Over the week, the experiment expanded from 30 students to 200! By the end of the week, Jones felt the experiment was getting out of hand, so he tricked the students and then explained that "they had been a part of an experiment to demonstrate how people willingly create a sense of superiority over others, and how this can lead people to justify doing horrible things in the name of the state’s honor" (paragraph 5).

Since the experiment was made to demonstrate "how people willingly create a sense of superiority over others, and how this can lead people to justify doing horrible things in the name of the state's honor", it had to develop like it was dictatorship in school. The first few days had to set rules that were similar to the rules that were set by the Nazis probably during a meeting. The experiment started to expand and more students joined in and improvement in academic skills improved after the second day.  By the third day, everyone had tasks to do like designing a Third Wave banner and more than 200 participants joined and non-members were discriminated. By the fourth day, almost everyone got involved and everyone was opening Jones like a leader. Jones thought this was too much for him to control, so he had to lie about a candidate that would replace him in television.  At the end of the week, there was a blank channel in the Th. That was when Jones announced everyone was part of the experiment over how "people create a sense of superiority over others and how this can lead to people justify doing horrible things in the name of the state's honor"

The third wave was able to develop over such a short amount of time because of the intrusive of mystery at first to "outsiders", and then the fact that many people around them were part of the third wave pressured them into the movement. The text states, "After only three days, the experiment took on a life of its own, with students from all over the school joining in. The class expanded from initial 30 students to 43 attendees". This quote showed that the growth may not have started rapidly, but later the text says that the group eventually had 200 members. One of the ways this was possible was that outside of class, students used the salute, intriguing those not involved and eventually allowing more people to join. Most people give in to peer pressure, but when everyone around you is doing something, isn't it hard to not do that same thing as well? The experiment proved this simply with a fake group, and one person starting the wave with a few instructions grew to 200 people following those same instructions. The experiment had to be ended simply because it grew out of control. Something so big could turn bad easily if let loose.

Ron Jones, a Highschool teacher at Cubberley High School in Polo Alto, California created an experiment to demonstrate to his students how people follow the crowds even in bad times. He Started this experiment called The Third Wave in april of 1967 and it went on for three days and it ended on the fourth because he realized that it was becoming too hard to handle and it was slipping out of his control. He started the experiment because he found it hard to explain what is called herd behavior and how much power a dictator can have alone over so many people. So he then created an authoritative dictatorship in his classroom to teach his students the German’s mentality. He then made many rules to go along with the dictatorship like the students have to stand up while participating in class etc.. The text in paragraph 1 states “History teacher Ron Jones, finding himself unable to explain to his students how people throughout history followed the crowd even when terrible things were happening, decided to demonstrate it to his students through an experiment.” This shows how and why he started the experiment and how it was hard to explain these things to his students. His students had become involved and loyal to the project.

The Third Wave started off with just 30 students and a small experiment to show the impact of crowds. In just a few days, there were over 200 members.The author states, "Jones instructed the students on how to initiate new members...","...stopping non-members from entering the class, or other tasks...". Jones had taught the students how to initiate new members and to not associate with non-members. The students did't question this they just went along with it because they wanted to be apart of the big group; do what everyone else was doing. In the text, the author explains, "... Jones felt it was slipping out of control. He decided terminate the movement...". Jones held a rally in which he told the students that a presidential candidate would be announced, but instead he explained that they all apart of an experiment. He also told them that he wanted to demonstrate "how people willingly create a sense of superiority over other, and how this can lead people to justify doing horrible things". Jones wanted to help the students understand how easily one can loose sense of right and wrong.

The Third Wave developed over such a short period of time because the students that joined the movement actively participated in spreading it, exemplified in the passage, "All of the students ... received a special assignment, like designing a Third Wave Banner, stopping non-members from entering the class, or other tasks to bring honor to the movement. Jones instructed the students on how to initiate new members, and by the end of the day the movement had over 200 participants." (CommonLit Staff 3) In essence, a sort of pyramid scheme was formed: groups of students that joined the movement actively encouraged other students to join, and these newly added students encouraged even more students to join; the cycle would continue. The experiment was ended because, "... the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control. He decided to terminate the movement ..." (CommonLit Staff 4) I think that this passage is relatively self-explanatory; Jones simply felt it was becoming out-of-control and wanted to end the experiment and to that it was an experiment to the students.

The Third Wave developed  rapidly because the students genuinely believed that it was the best course of action. Their grades, accomplishments, and classparticipation/ behavior had improved dramatically since the experiment began. There did not seem to be any consequences in the students eyes. They became extremely engaged in all the Third Wave activities both inside and outside tha classroom. The experiment ended because the students were so patriotic about the "movement". The history class of thirty rapidly grew to 200 in three days.  That means 170 students joined a school "movement" in two days. Thats 85 people per day! On the fifth and final day all the students had completely believed that the "Third Wave" was a movement that would expel democracy. They believed a candidate from the "movement" would announce its existance on television after five days of its success. The creator, Ron Jones, believed it had gone too far and for everyone's safety he shut it down.  If he hadn't the fake organization would have grown into something out of his controls. The Third Wave only lasted for a week. It could have spilled into the American version of the Nazi Party, which is the opposite of what America stands for.

Ron Jones, a high school teacher, found himself unable to explain to students how people often followed the crowd throughout history, even when bad things were happening.  He decided to demonstrate it to his students though an experiment called the third wave. The experiment started out well with drastic improvement in the students academic skills, so Jones gave instructions to his students on how to recruit new members. It quickly spread throughout the school,” by the end of the day the movement had over 200 participants”(3). In just three days the experiment went from 30 students to 200, clearly the students were devoted and eager to join this project. The students were so loyal to this project that they would report to Jones if another student failed to abide by the rules.  Jones began to feel like the experiment was working a bit too well and feared it was getting out of control. The reader is shown this when, “the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control”(4).  Jones began to feel that the experiment was getting out of hand so he decided to reveal to his students that it was an experiment.

The Third Wave experiment was a huge success in showing the young generations on how people followed the crowd, even if it was unethical. This event was conducted by Mr. Jones a history teacher, which was surprised by the number of students joined in on the experiment. This event caught on because it was more normal to participate then not to. You were looked at as weird and wrong for not joining in. The students even started reporting each other for not doing their specific duties. "Jones was surprised that some of the students started reporting to him when other members of the movement failed to abide by the rules." paragraph 3. The students saw huge improvements in their grades and felt empowered, so there only a benefit for them. The experiment ended by Jones called the members to a rally. Jones stated that the president was announcing the national use of the program. "He decided to terminate the movement, so he lied to students by announcing that the Third Wave was a part of a nationwide movement and that on the next day a presidential candidate of the movement would publicly announce its existence on television." paragraph 4. He presented them a blank Th to snap them out of the Nazi mindset. Overall, the project was very effective in teaching the students.

"The Third Wave", written by the Common Lit Staff, was a story about a history teacher at a high school found himself unable to explain to his students how people throughout history followed the crowd even when terrible things were happening. The wave developed over such a short period by the students getting involved in the experiment to see what Jones was talking about. This statement is simply saying that the experiment started to take a route that no one really expected, especially Jones. Students from all over started to tell Jones on other members that failed to abide by the rules and the loyalty was outstanding. With this being said, Jones felt it was getting out of control so he decided to terminate the movement. It states in paragraph 4," By the fourth day of the experiment, the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control." The statement explains why Jones felt he had to end the experiment. This short story is explaining how people can get out of control when following a crowd which is what Jones found out and he had to end the experiment.

The Third Wave experiment began as Ron Jones initially announced he was "starting a movement aimed to eliminate democracy."(The Third Wave 1) By naming the movement "The Third Wave" and creating a motto that emphasizes a focus on strength through the campaign, Jones was able to create an influential area in his classroom where students would willingly join in. From there, Jones began to enforce and emphasize the importance of discipline and conformity to the authoritarian figure, Jones, created in the classroom. Students learned and complied quickly, and Jones took a step further, requiring students use the salute he created to each other even outside of class where Jones was not present. Consequently, the decline caused improvement in students's academic skills and soon enough, the number of students in the class grew rapidly. "the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control."(The Third Wave 4) Observing the speed at which other students were willing to conform and join the movement, Jones believed the experiment was becoming out of hand; he decided to end the experiment, ultimately revealing that the "movement" demonstrated how people can be lead to justify bad things in the guise of honor from the sense of superiority they create over others.

The Third wave developed over such a short time by Jones drilling students the way he wanted his class to be. He told hs students that they had to stand up to answer and ask a question which had to be in 3 words or less.  They also "were required to preface, begin, each remark with “Mr. Jones.” (Paragraph 2)  Jones also had the students greet eachother in and outside of class with a solute that was like the Nazi regime.  After 3 days the initial 30 students went up to 42 participating in the Third Wave. This was only the beginning as the amount of attendees went up to 200 by the end of the school day.  That was just one part of why the experiment was ended. "By the fourth day of the experiment, the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control." (Paragraph 4) Jones had to tell the students that the whole nation was a part of this and it would be proven on the television on Friday. When Friday came, they were told that it was an experiment to prove that people can be willing to try and put themselves above people. This was told to the students after they were watching a blank channel of the television for a few minutes.

The Third Wave was developed over such a short period of time because Ron Jones a history teacher, was trying to explain to his students why individuals follow the crowd even when they see that certain actions are wrong. The teacher created a movement which he encouraged for the students to join. The movement's purpose was to eliminate democracy, and one of the central points that Jones provided was that, " democracy's main weakness is that it favors the individual over the whole community" ( The Third Wave 1).  Moreover, he encouraged them even more to join by creating a catchy motto that read, "Strength through discipline, strength through community, strength thought action, strength through pride" ( The Third Wave 1). When the students joined the movement, not only they followed every single rule put by Jones, rules such as calling him Mr.Jones for every remark they wanted to make. They had to be fitted and saying attention before the second bell, had to stand up every time one asked a question with three words or fewer. These were strict rules, rules that they were not used to. Yet, they followed them. Moreover, the experiment ended because Jones got a little worried that these experiment was getting a little out of control. The students were too loyal and their discipline was outstanding. They were taking this movement very seriously.

The Third Wave was an anti-democracy movement conducted by Ron Jones, a history teacher at Cubberley High School in Polo Alto, C. He started this experiment in 1967, in an attempt to teach his students how groups of people throughout history have had the advantage of influencing others to follow their path, regardless of how nefarious their actions were. He wanted to show the students first hand how this movement worked. He announced that he was starting a movement to eliminate democracy, and he started to get his students involved immediately. Jones installed extensive rules and proper disciplinary skills into his students by the end of the first day. The movement picked up steam, and by the third day, the movement expended to over 40 students. They even had a salute resembling that of the Nazi regime. Everyone obeyed Jones. However, by the fourth day, more than 200 students joined in on the bandwagon, and the experiment was getting out of control. Therefore, Jones decided to end it by tracking his students into thinking that the Third Wave was a nationwide movement and that a Presidential Candidate would officially confirm its existence. in the end, that definitely did not happen. Instead, Jones simply announced that the students were a part of an experiment and that he was trying to show them how a group of people can band together to brainwashed others and create a sense of superiority.

Jones was surprised that some of the students started reporting to him when other members of the movement failed to abide by the rules." Jones was also scared of how serious it was getting and stopped it.

The way that the Third Wave experiment developed over the five days that it was exponential; the ending number of participants made the original number pale in comparison to the original number.  The main reason that the experiment was able to grow as fast as it did in the short amount of time that it was active was because of the way that the experiment looked to those outside of it. The author says "All of the students were issued a member card and each of them received a special assignment, like designing a Third Wave Banner, stopping non-members from entering the class, or other tasks to bring honor to the movement," (CommonLit 3). It is common knowledge that envy and jealousy are present in every human being, and this must be the reason that so many outside students joined. As described in the quote, there were many things within the experiment that were exclusive of outside students. The students out of the experiment must have felt a desire to join in with the other students, an indirect form of peer pressure, if you will. The experiment was ended early due to its rapidly increasing intensity, and the operator of the experiment feared what would become of it were it to continue, thus he ended it. Jones' fear is expressed in the quote, "By the fourth day of the experiment, the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control," (CommonLit 5). It is clearly expressed that Jones was fearful of the students' increasing intensity and thus decided to end it, especially through the description "that Jones felt it was slipping out of control.

The Third Wave developed over such a short period of time because of how seriously the students reacted to the regime of the Third Wave. After the reading explains what rules were outlined to students, the text states, "As the week went on, Jones’ class transformed into a group with a supreme sense of discipline and community.  [...] This resulted in dramatic improvements to the efficiency, or orderliness, of the class. [...] After only three days, the experiment took on a life of its own, with students from all over the school joining in. The class expanded from initial 30 students to 43 attendees" (CommonLit). This cluster of text routes shows how legitimately the student took directions because the students did not even hesitate to follow orders nor did they question the ethics of some of the rules. For example, not a single student questioned the morals of the salute when it was purposefully intended to resemble that of the Nazi regime's salute. This not only proves how naive minor's can be to their superiors but also demonstrates how quickly society can follow one another when the majority is committing said action. This is the classic case that everyone and their neighbor's mom told you as a kid: "If your friend jumped off a bridge would you jump too?"- in this case and many, yes, you would be more likely to commit an action, even if it may be questionable, if your peers are also participating in the action. This fact connects back not only many examples throughout human history but in varying life forms across the globe. Birds for example learn to fly, walk, eat, etc. by watching their siblings and following the mother. It is human nature to follow the pack and unfortunately it is not always a benefit to society.

The Third Wave started as a experiment only Jones knew was actually one. The students were told it was a new movement, and that it would eliminate democracy. Jones also predicted it would bring more discipline and authority to the class and others in the school. After the first day of the experiment, Jones made it to where the class had to follow strict orders involving discipline and authority. They were told to salute one another outside of class and after three days students from all over the school were joining in. The students showed drastic improvements on academic skills and motivation. The students could stop non-members from entering the class and he instructed them on how to create new members. By the fourth day, the students were showing so much discipline and loyalty that Jones decided it was getting out of control. He made the students attend a rally where he announced that this was an experiment to show how people willingly follow the crowd or create a sense of superior over others leading to horrible things. This experiment developed over such a short period of time because that is what happens when the whole crowd is telling people to support or be a certain way. This happens in real life and only takes a short amount of time since so many people are following one thing or idea and it spreads rapidly. The experiment ended because Jones realized first of all that if the experiment went on any longer it would lead to an authoritarian school and result in something much more than a experiment if it went on. He also noticed that it worked out too perfectly probably and that it was time to go ahead and end the experiment since it was a success already. Jones was also not in control of it really anymore since so many students joined and took authority over it. He knew it was time to bring his main lesson across clearly to all the students at the school instead of continuing what he was against and let it get even more out of control.

The Third Wave developed in such a short period of time because the students were required to salute other classmates outside of class and saw improvements in grades. In the text, it states that Mr.Jones made the members of his class salute each other, even in his absence. "Jones made up a salute resembling that of the Nazi regime and ordered class members to salute each other even outside the class. They all obeyed this command." The students all ended up opening his command as stated, causing the other kids in the school to recognize that students were salting each other. The other students became interested and wanted to join. When they learned that the students who were seen salting each other around the halls were seeing improvements in grades, it gave them another reason to want to join the class. The class had grown by 13 students after only three days. "The class expanded from initial 30 students to 43 attendees." Mr. Jones recognized this increase and then taught his students how to initiate new members, growing the numbers even more. "Jones instructed the students on how to initiate new members, and by the end of the day, the movement had over 200 participants. " The initiation training led to the classes immense growth over such a short period of time, as proved by the quote. By the time the fourth day had rolled around, Mr. Jones felt like he was losing control of the experiment and had to end it. "...the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control. He decided to terminate the movement..." Had Mr. Jones not lost his grip on the experiment, perhaps he would have continued it longer as it did show improvements in grades and popularity. Had Mr. Jones not terminated the project, he could have ended up creating the next Nazi Regime on accident. In conclusion, Mr. Jones successfully demonstrated how groups followed the crowd, through the commencement and termination of his experiment The Third Wave.

The Third Wave, a five-day experiment conducted by Ron Jones, was created for the history teacher to help his students understand how people in horrific historical events had followed the crowd in the wake of terrible things. He started the experiment small, by inviting students to join a movement title. 'The Third Wave", which aimed to bring down democracy. The movement stated out small in his classroom, by having kids practice proper seating and abide by strict rules with him as their leader. Jones noticed that as the week went on, students had "a supreme sense of discipline and community" (CommonLit Staff) and even followed the Nazi-like salute Jones had made up. By the third day, the movement had tons of students involved all of whom showed, "a drastic improvement in academic skills and tremendous motivation" (CommonLit Staff). All members were issued a member card and given a specific task/assignment to honor the movement. As members started to learn how to recruit more people, membership increased to over 200 students. They asked questions in three words or less and preface all their statements with "Mr.Jones". By the experiment's fourth day, Jones saw an alarming amount of loyalty and dedication to the movement. So much, that he knew he had to shut it down, before it got out of control. To reveal that the whole movement had been an experiment, Jones convinced his students that a presidential candidate of the nationally-recognized movement was publicly announcing it's existence on T.V., and ordered them all to a noon rally on Friday. When the students got to the rally, all they saw was a blank screen. Jones revealed that they had been part of an experiment to show how quickly people will join a group to prove their superiority over others or have a sense of community no matter the type of community. He also explained how people will excuse any actions as contribution to the movement or classify it for "the name of the state's honor" (CommonLit Staff). He had to shut the experiment down because the movement was getting ot of control and people were involving themselves into something that they knew little about. As people started to gain a false sense of confidence in the movement, they excused weird and controlled behaviors in the name of the movement.
